stem: The nurse is caring for a client with type 1 diabetes mellitus who requires insulin. Based on the client's medication administration record (MAR), lab results, and care plan, match the insulin type to its expected onset, peak, and duration.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:00 SBAR for patient, John Smith, DOB 03/15/1988, MRN 1234567. 
Situation: Patient admitted for diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) secondary to insulin omission. Currently, patient is alert and oriented, but reports feeling weak and nauseous. Blood glucose elevated.
Background: Patient has a history of type 1 diabetes for 15 years. Usually well-controlled with insulin pump, but pump malfunctioned 2 days ago and patient did not administer insulin via alternative subcutaneous injection method. Admitted yesterday at 18:00 with initial blood glucose of 450 mg/dL. DKA protocol initiated.
Assessment: Current vital signs: HR 110, BP 110/70, RR 24 and deep, Temp 99.8°F (37.7°C), SpO2 96% on room air. Blood glucose currently 280 mg/dL. Urine ketones large. Patient receiving intravenous fluids and insulin infusion per DKA protocol.
Recommendation: Continue to monitor blood glucose every hour and adjust insulin infusion rate as needed. Monitor electrolytes, especially potassium. Provide patient education on alternative subcutaneous insulin administration in case of future pump malfunction. Ensure patient eats regularly once tolerating oral intake. Consult diabetes educator prior to discharge. 07:30 Notified MD of patient status. Orders received to decrease insulin infusion per protocol, continue monitoring vitals and labs. Will check patient's blood glucose in one hour. -- Nurse Jane Doe, RN

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content:
LabValueNormal Range
Glucose280 mg/dL70-110 mg/dL
Potassium3.2 mEq/L3.5-5.0 mEq/L
Sodium138 mEq/L135-145 mEq/L
BUN25 mg/dL10-20 mg/dL
Creatinine1.3 mg/dL0.6-1.2 mg/dL
pH7.307.35-7.45
HCO316 mEq/L22-26 mEq/L
Ketones (Urine)LargeNegative

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: Alert and oriented x3. Skin warm and dry. Mucous membranes dry. Lungs clear to auscultation. Heart rate regular, tachycardia present. Abdomen soft, non-tender. Neurological exam intact. Peripheral pulses present in all extremities, but slightly diminished. No edema noted.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
- Monitor blood glucose hourly.
- Administer insulin infusion per DKA protocol.
- Monitor potassium levels and administer potassium replacement as needed.
- Provide intravenous fluids (Normal Saline) at 200 mL/hr.
- Monitor urine output.
- Provide patient education on diabetes management.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
MedicationDosageRouteFrequencyLast Administered
Insulin Aspart (Novolog)5 unitsSubcutaneousBefore meals and at bedtimeN/A (patient NPO)
Insulin Glargine (Lantus)20 unitsSubcutaneousOnce daily at bedtimeYesterday at 22:00
Insulin Lispro (Humalog)Sliding ScaleSubcutaneousBefore meals and at bedtimeN/A (patient NPO)
Insulin Regular (Humulin R)Sliding ScaleIVContinuous InfusionOngoing

columns.text: Onset: 15-30 min; Peak: 0.5-2.5 hr; Duration: 3-6 hr
Onset: 0.5-1 hr; Peak: 1-5 hr; Duration: 6-10 hr
Onset: 70 min; Peak: 1-3 hr; Duration: Up to 24 hr
Onset: 1-2 hr; Peak: 6-14 hr; Duration: 16-24 hr

rationale.correct:
Correct answers are:
Insulin Lispro (Humalog) - Onset: 15-30 min; Peak: 0.5-2.5 hr; Duration: 3-6 hr.
Insulin Regular (Humulin R) - Onset: 0.5-1 hr; Peak: 1-5 hr; Duration: 6-10 hr.
Insulin Aspart (Novolog) - Onset: 15-30 min; Peak: 0.5-2.5 hr; Duration: 3-6 hr.
Insulin Glargine (Lantus) - Onset: 1-2 hr; Peak: No peak; Duration: 24 hr.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect answers indicate a lack of understanding of the onset, peak, and duration of different types of insulin.

answerBreakdown.rationale: Insulin lispro is a rapid-acting insulin analog. It has an onset of 15-30 minutes, peaks in 0.5-2.5 hours, and has a duration of 3-6 hours. It is used to cover insulin needs for meals eaten at the same time. Given its rapid onset, it is essential to administer it close to mealtime to avoid hypoglycemia.

Regular insulin is a short-acting insulin. It has an onset of 0.5-1 hour, peaks in 1-5 hours, and has a duration of 6-10 hours. It is often administered before meals and can also be given intravenously in emergency situations like DKA. Because of its longer duration, clients need to be monitored for hypoglycemia longer than with rapid-acting insulins.

Insulin aspart is a rapid-acting insulin analog, similar to insulin lispro. It has an onset of 15-30 minutes, peaks in 0.5-2.5 hours, and has a duration of 3-6 hours. It is used to cover insulin needs for meals eaten at the same time. It is administered subcutaneously and should be given shortly before or after starting a meal.

Insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin. It has a relatively slow onset of 1-2 hours, has a minimal peak (sometimes described as 'peakless'), and has a prolonged duration of up to 24 hours. It provides a basal level of insulin coverage and is typically administered once daily at the same time each day. It should not be mixed with other insulins.

clinicalPearls: Rapid-acting insulins like lispro and aspart are used for mealtime coverage due to their quick onset.
Regular insulin can be administered intravenously in emergencies like DKA.
Long-acting insulins like glargine provide a basal level of insulin and should not be mixed with other insulins.
Always consider the patient's individual needs and blood glucose levels when determining insulin dosages.

questionTrap.trap: Students may confuse the onset, peak, and duration of different insulin types, especially the rapid-acting insulins. They also might not differentiate between short-acting (Regular) and long-acting (Glargine) insulins.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Emphasize the importance of memorizing the onset, peak, and duration for each insulin type. Use visual aids and mnemonics to help differentiate between them. Practice with case studies to apply this knowledge in a clinical context.

mnemonic.title: Rapid-Acting Insulin Mnemonic
mnemonic.expansion: Lispro and Aspart are like 'LASERs' - they act FAST! (Rapid Onset)
